passages.text: Reiterate Buy; lower TP to MYR8.80

2Q25 results slightly below, mainly due to IDR's depreciation vs MYR: CIMB's 2Q25 adjusted NPATAMI at MYR1.9bn was down \(4\%\) y- y and q- q, with 1H25 NPATAMI forming \(49\%\) of both our previous and Bloomberg consensus estimates. The slight miss was because of CIMB's outsized Indonesia exposure (vs other Malaysian banking peers) and the sharp depreciation of IDR vs MYR \((- 9\%\) y- y) affecting earnings, but underlying constant currency performance was in- line. Apart from this, there was a slight NIM compression (- 1bp q- q) and higher provisions, but good cost control and non- interest income performance offset these. CIMB announced an interim dividend of 19.75sen/ share (vs 20sen/share and special dividend of 7sen/share in 1H24) and indicated that \(55.5\%\) payout will form the floor; we see opportunity for higher payout, provided earnings/capital in 2H25F are supportive. Overall, given high market expectations going into results, we think broad trends were as expected.

FY25 guidance unchanged except for NIM: Management lowered its NIM guidance to 5- 8bp compression (vs 0- 5 bp compression earlier) due to Malaysia's overnight policy rate (OPR) cut, and Thailand's effective interest rate (EIR) adjustment. We see sequential NIM compression in Malaysia and Singapore in 3Q25 due to lower rates. The rest of the guidance was unchanged - constant currency loan growth of \(5 - 7\%\) for FY25E (higher than \(4.8\%\) y- y growth in 2024, to be driven by the growth in Malaysia [5- 6%] and Indonesia [5- 7%]); CIMB will continue to follow a deposit- led strategy to drive asset growth; CTI \( = 14\%\) , with proactive capital management; dividend payout ratio of \(55\%\) ; ROE of \(11.0 - 11.5\%\) . As per management, the drag from reported earnings (from Indonesia) due to FX translation should be mitigated by the strong performance in Malaysia and Singapore, and therefore reiterated ROE guidance.

Lower TP to MYR8.80; maintain Buy: We reduce our loan growth/NIM outlook due to the risks of stronger MYR/policy rate cuts. We recommend CIMB despite the muted FY25F guidance, as we think the F30 strategy points to continued realistic ROE/dividend expansion goals backed by NOI. Key F30 thrusts are seeing good progress: (1) Capital: payout ratio floor of \(55\%\) , (2) Cash: CASA build and successful reduction of cost of funds; (3) Cross- sell: Strong growth in fee and commission income, treasury client sales, and wealth management (+10% in AUM); (4) Capabilities: Continued investment in technology; CIR targeted to remain stable or improve. We lower our Gordon Growth model- derived TP to MYR8.80 (from MYR8.90 previously; \(- 18\%\) implied upside), which is based on a cost of equity of \(9.4\%\) (unchanged), long- term growth rate of \(3\%\) (unchanged), and average FY26F- 27F ROE of \(11.2\%\) (vs \(11.3\%\) earlier). The stock currently trades at 1.1x FY25F P/B.
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates
Target priceMYR 8.80Reduced from MYR 8.90
Implied upside+18.4%

Valuations and ratios
Source: Company data, Nomura estimates

CIMB Group is a leading focused ASEAN bank. The Group is headquartered in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and offers Consumer Banking, Commercial Banking, Wholesale Banking, Islamic Banking, Wealth Management and Digital Payment Products and Services. It is the fifth largest banking group by assets in ASEAN and, as at the end of March 2024, had over 34,000 staff and around 25 million customers. CIMB Group Holdings Berhad has been listed on the Malaysian stock exchange since 1987. As at 31 March 2024, total assets stood at MYR757.9 billion, with total shareholders' funds of MYR67.7 billion and total Islamic assets of MYR212.3 billion.

We value CIMB on Gordon Growth model using cost of equity of \(9.4\%\) , long term growth rate of \(3\%\) and average ROE (2026F- 27F) of \(11.2\%\) to arrive at our target price of MYR8.80. The benchmark index for this stock is KLCI Index.

Downside risks include: 1) prolonged slow loans growth and asset quality shocks due to economic slowdown; 2) continuous slowdown in loans and deposits growth; 3) steep NIM compression; and 4) negative surprises on asset quality.

Based on the strength and progress of CIMB's ESG roadmap, our ESG scores for CIMB, on our 5 point scale, are as follows: E (4.0), S (4.1) and G (4.0). Our E score is based on progress and plans on net zero GHG emissions pathway by 2050, and works starting on the cement and coal sector transition. Our S score is raised due to efforts towards SME and retail financial inclusion and sustainability financing. Our G score is up as the bank, under the leadership of Dato' Rahman, has improved ROE, de- risked its underperforming book, improved capital buffers and improved dividend payouts. This brings CIMB's overall ESG score to 4.0.

Key highlights - FX translation a drag: (1) Loans down \(0.3\% q - q(+0.5\%\) on a constant currency basis) due to a decline in wholesale banking loans (especially from Malaysia) as the bank remains disciplined on loan pricing; deposits up \(0.9\% q - q / + 2.7\% y - y(+1.5\% q - q / + 4.9\% y - y\) on constant currency basis); q-q uptick driven by \(1.2\% q - q\) growth in CASA deposits, partially offset by \(0.5\% q - q\) decline in FDs. The CASA ratio was higher q-q at \(44.9\% v s 44.7\%\) in 1Q25; (2) Banking book/group NIM was down 2bp/1bp q-q; (3) Net credit cost was higher q-q at 36bp vs 26bp in 1Q25 due to lower writebacks and timing of overlay reallocation (additional MYR500mn overlays related to macroeconomic uncertainties vs MYR100mn in 1Q25); (4) GIL ratio was marginally lower at \(2.15\%\) vs \(2.16\%\) in 1Q25; (5) Opex was down \(1.1\% q - q\) ; CTI was lower q-q at \(45.5\% v s 46.9\%\) in 1Q25; and (5) NOII was up \(5\% q - q\) due to higher trading income and NPL sales partially offset by a decline in fee & commission income.

Loans growth - IDR translation and weak wholesale: CIMB's 2Q25 loans were down \(0.3\% q - q\) in MYR terms due to a decline in wholesale banking loans (especially Malaysia, due to tariff uncertainties and bond markets offering better pricing), and additional drag from Indonesia due to FX translation. On a constant currency basis, loans were up \(0.5\% q - q / 3.6\% y - y\) . In 2025, management is maintaining loan growth target of \(5 - 7\% y - y\) , with Malaysia contributing the most to the higher growth, but this is in constant currency terms. The bank expects loans in Malaysia to grow at \(5 - 6\% y - y\) in 2025, and in Indonesia it expects loan growth of \(5 - 7\%\) . Management mentioned that it will continue to follow a deposit-led strategy to drive its asset growth. With tariffs uncertainty reducing, management is expecting wholesale loans to pick up in Malaysia in 2H25 due to stronger pipeline.

Deposits growth intact: up \(0.9\% q - q / + 2.7\% y - y(+1.5\% q - q / + 4.9\% y - y\) on constant currency basis); q-q uptick driven by \(1.2\% q - q\) growth in CASA deposits (primarily driven by non- retail CASA - commercial and wholesale segment), partially offset by \(0.5\% q - q\) decline in FDs. The CASA ratio was higher q-q at \(44.9\% v s 44.7\%\) in 1Q25. In local currency terms, CASA ratio was higher in all its markets (Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and Indonesia) vs Mar- 25. CIMB remains focussed on its deposits- led strategy.

Net interest margin compression under control: NIM was down 1bp q-q due to rate cuts regionally and accounting change in Thailand. Given the extent of rate cuts, the negative effect of rate cuts on NIM was much more milder as it was partially mitigated by funding cost management, in our view. By geography, Malaysia saw 1bp expansion q-q (lower cost of funds as the bank managed to reduce the dependency on expensive short term funding), Singapore NIM was up 16bp q-q (as deposits priced lower) while Indonesia saw NIM contraction of 6bp q-q (pressure on yields) and Thailand recorded a steep NIM compression of 35bp q-q (impact of rate cut, and one- off accounting impact of EIR worth of MYR30mn on NII). Refer to Fig. 3 for a breakdown of banking/treasury book NIM and also a geographical breakdown of NIMs. Management lowered its NIM guidance to 5- 8bp compression (vs 0- 5 bp compression earlier), mainly due to Malaysia and Thailand. Management sees sequential NIM compression in Malaysia and Singapore in 3Q25 due to lower rates. As per management, it will continue to mitigate the negative impact of rate cuts on NIM by active liability management.

Asset quality benign: The gross impaired loan (GIL) ratio improved marginally to \(2.15\%\) vs \(2.16\%\) in 1Q25. Net credit cost was higher q-q at 36bp vs 26bp in 1Q25 due to lower writebacks and timing of overlay reallocation (additional MYR500mn of overlays related to macroeconomic uncertainties vs MYR100mn in 1Q25). Of the additional MYR500mn overlays, \(2 / 3^{rd}\) was allocated into retail portfolio while remaining \(1 / 3^{rd}\) into non- retail (mostly in SME). Loan- loss coverage was lower at \(- 98\%\) vs \(- 102\%\) in end- 1Q25. Management is maintaining a net credit cost guidance of 25- 35bp for FY25E. Management had earlier guided that CIMB's exposure to trade- related sectors is \(20\%\) revenue from the US. Management had also mentioned that the second- order impact of trade tariffs will also be limited for CIMB as its commercial book is relatively small at \(
came through, as per management. CTI was lower q-q at \(45.5\%\) vs \(46.9\%\) in 1Q25. Management expects CTI to be \(

Valuation Methodology We value CIMB on Gordon Growth model using cost of equity of \(9.4\%\) , long term growth rate of \(3\%\) and average ROE (2026F- 27F) of \(11.2\%\) to arrive at our target price of MYR8.80. The benchmark index for this stock is KLCI Index.

Risks that may impede the achievement of the target price Downside risks include: 1) prolonged slow loans growth and asset quality shocks due to economic slowdown; 2) continuous slowdown in loans and deposits growth; 3) steep NIM compression; and 4) negative surprises on asset quality.
